body: Merged. Thanks Greg!

I'm not comforatble with the container-specific code, so I think we need to abandon that here and switch to using `javax.servlet.ServletRegistration`. All we need to do is add support for that into `ServletRegistrationBean`.  Probably to reach feature parity with this patch we need to scoop up a bean of type `MultipartConifgElement` and register it with the "free" servlets (i.e. the ones that do not already have a `ServletRegistrationBean`) - that would be in  `EmbeddedWebApplicationContext.getServletContextInitializerBeans()` if you want to revise and re-submit.
I'm not sure about how to use ServletRegistrationBean by itself, hence I don't know how to modify it in this context to add extra support.

The `ServletRegistrationBean` just provides simple getters/setters to configure a servlet. It is similar to the servlet element in web.xml. The magic happens in the `configure` method, it simply delegates to servlet 3.0 `ServletRegistration.Dynamic`. We would need to call `setMultiPartConfig` here, probably from a local property.

The `EmbeddedWebApplicationContext` has some additional logic that allows `Servlet` beans to be picked up if there are no `ServletRegistrationBean`s. We would need some additional logic here as well.

Breakthrough! Since I updated my test code with this:

``` java
        this.context = new AnnotationConfigEmbeddedWebApplicationContext(
                ContainerWithEverythingTomcat.class,
                WebMvcAutoConfiguration.class,
                MultipartAutoConfiguration.class);
```

...it seems the servlet is getting created and I can see my tweaks working. Let me work on this some more, and I might have an updated patch to inspect on Monday.

The CI is now fixed and it builds locally for me. Could you let me know if this is still an issue.

There were two things AFAIR. First, I think the defaults have some logging set to `DEBUG` and that overwhelmed me quite a bit when trying to understand what's going in in my various attempts to get the test setup working. Second, as a user I think it's way easier to simply alter a log level in a pre-existing configuration file in the project than having to create a new one from scratch once I'd like to alter a log level or change the layout slightly.

But yeah, that's not terribly important I guess :).

The default log configuration is all INFO, so I'd like to see your log output to work out what you did different. On the second point, I agree, and I'm sure people will continue to use log config files in sample projects, but for the boot samples I also feel that unless there is a compelling reason to change the defaults we should stick to the minimal set of files to make the app run. So thanks for the feedback.

I am not sure about commit d2dd0cd, it seems to add a lot of noise to the maven POM and I am not sure the benefit is worth it for a couple of reasons:
1) We are trying to be opinionated about the dependencies and discourage changes
2) If you do want to update the version locally you can just override our version in the usual maven way. This is obviously more XML than just adding a property but is arguably easier to understand.

Thanks for fixes!

PS. Could you clone your own copy of the repo for any future pull requests rather than pushing directly to this one. I have started naming my remotes `springsource` `philwebb` rather than `upstream` `origin` to prevent accidentally pushing to the wrong place.

> If you do want to update the version locally you can just override our version in the usual maven way. This is obviously more XML than just adding a property but is arguably easier to understand.

The whole point of this commit is that your suggested way does _not_ work and extracting the version into a property is the only way to achieve library upgrades. Dependency versions specified in a `<dependencyManagement />` block are enforced by Maven. Locally defined version numbers are not considered at all. Thus there's no way to tweak the dependency version in the user project. 

While I can perfectly understand the basic reasoning it's usually the lower version bound you want to enforce. However assume we fix a critical bug in a Spring Data library and release it. If there's no way for the user to upgrade to that bug fix version except waiting for a Boot release, Boot is more of an annoyance than a help. So while I am totally with you that altering the version is probably not something you want to start with but it definitely is something users will want to do. Even more for third party dependencies, whose release lifecycle we don't control.

I'd argue that if someone takes the time to lookup the property to override and manually declares and configures the property locally, she knows what she's doing. I don't expect people to abuse the functionality to deliberately pull in unsupported library versions such as Spring 3, HIbernate 3 or the like.

Does redeclaring the dependencyManagement section not work for you?

For example, using the sample from the README

```
$ mvn dependency:list | grep spring-core
[INFO]    org.springframework:spring-core:jar:4.0.0.M2:compile
```

After adding:

```
    <dependencyManagement>
        <dependencies>
            <dependency>
                <groupId>org.springframework</groupId>
                <artifactId>spring-core</artifactId>
                <version>4.0.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT</version>
            </dependency>
        </dependencies>
    </dependencyManagement>
```

```
$ mvn dependency:list | grep spring-core
[INFO]    org.springframework:spring-core:jar:4.0.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT:compile
```

Admittedly, I haven't thought about adding a `<dependencyManagement />` block but if that's the solution to the problem there's 

a) no aspect of being opinionated here anymore as you can screw up the version just as you could do with the properties approach and
b) were exposing 9 lines of XML to a user which can be simply 1 with the properties approach. Not what I consider "simplifying" :)

What if we started with exposing the libraries only in the first place? I can see the argument that it's unlikely people would wanna upgrade the build plugins too regularly.

You aren't using `SpringApplication` to load your context in the non-embedded case so you would have to add some initializers to match that behaviour. In particular you aren't loading and binding to the `application.properties`, so it isn't setting the `ddl-auto` property, and the SQL script is not being executed as a result. You could fix this in your `web.xml` (in the servlet declaration)

```
<init-param>
    <param-name>contextInitializerClasses</param-name>
    <param-value>org.springframework.boot.context.initializer.ConfigFileApplicationContextInitializer</param-value>
</init-param>
```

It's probably better though to add a `SpringBootServletInitializer`, since that way you are always going to get all the features of `SpringApplication` in your web context (then you would use a Servlet 3.0 container - so no need for web.xml). Your `SampleWebApplication` could extend `SpringBootServletInitializer` and just return an array containing its own class (that's a pretty common pattern for these "hybrid" builds").

You implementation of `registerStompEndpoints()` and mine are effectively the same.  I've chosen a different endpoint name (I'm not wedded to it) and not added SockJS support.  I've been informed that adding it at all times doesn't cause an issue so the auto-configuration could have that.

The use of `enableSimpleBroker()` does indeed bypass the endpoints; in essence it _doesn't_ route to your app.  So, maybe my `configured.setAnnotationMethodDestinationPrefixes("/app")` and your `configurer.enableSimpleBroker("/topic/")`.  The Portfolio sample maps [both `/queue/` and `/topic/`](https://github.com/rstoyanchev/spring-websocket-portfolio/blob/master/src/main/java/org/springframework/samples/portfolio/config/WebSocketConfig.java) so maybe all three are candidates for defaults.

As to the scanning, doesn't Spring already index all of that information when it scans for other things?  I might be making that up though.

There appear to be 2 design issues to sort out before we can move ahead on this. How to: 1) detect that the user wants to enable a webSocket MessageBroker; 2) decide whether to add a broker relay and what to do with the simple broker. With 2), maybe the user wants us to enable a broker relay for production use, but use a simple broker with the same routing keys if in development. Spring profiles seem like an obvious way to approach that, but Spring Boot does not currently bless any special profile names, and I prefer not to create a precedent. Also maybe that's _not_ what the user wants. 1) is  also tricky, even if Spring made bean definition class metadata searchable (it doesn't as far as I know), because it isn't obvious that a webSocket MessageBroker is the intended recipient of `@MessageMapping` or `@SubscribeEvent`. On the other hand, I suppose, arguably the developer who adds a `@MessageMapping` is happy to get a message from any source, so maybe it would be OK to always `setAnnotationMethodDestinationPrefixes`. It's probably best to throw that open for discussion.

I'm not sure whether to treat this as a bug or not (except the documentation is clearly wrong).  The problem is that the port is set in an `EmbeddedServletContainerCustomizer` that is (necessarily) applied to your container factory after it is created.

There are (at least) 4 other ways of setting the server port default:
1. As you discovered in `application.properties` (or `.yml).
2. Define a bean of type `ServerProperties` and setting the defaults there
3. On the command line
4. In the default args (or `Environment`) when you create the `SpringApplication`

I would have hoped that defining a bean of type `EmbeddedServletContainerCustomizer` would do it, and maybe even your version (undecided on that), but neither does as of 0.5.0.M5.  I'll have a think about both and get back to you.

One thing is unusual about your application: it doesn't have a Spring DispatcherServlet. Maybe that's common in Vaadin land (I have no experience with that)., but it isn't common in general. That's not to say that you can't convert you app, but it might not be suitable as a case study for Spring MVC apps in general.

The first thing you have to decide is what the target is. Do you want an executable JAR, or a WAR? If the former, then maybe the latter is a useful first step anyway.

You should be able to just create an application configuration main class (like the samples and guides) and import the XML file to get started. To run as a WAR in a container you will need a `SpringBootServletInitializer`. That will get you something that runs, but won't be serving your resources yet. Then you can probably start removing stuff from the XML that Boot already provides by autoconfiguration. Without access to the file it's hard to say how smoothly that would go.

A `Servlet` is added to a Spring Boot standalone application by adding a `@Bean` of type `Servlet` (or `ServletRegistrationBean` for more control of mapping and parameters).

This application only has one servlet. What is the purpose of the /\* mapping? Normally this would be a Spring DispatcherServlet in an autoconfigured Boot application, so that will be the only complicated piece. I imagine you can probably just create a `@Bean` definition for it, but you will have to take steps to disable the default `DispatcherServlet`. Looking at `DispatcherServletAutoConfiguration` I'd say you might only be able to do that by declaring your own `DispatcherServlet` and mapping it to an unused path. (Or if `SpringVaadinServlet` actually _is_ a `DispatcherServlet`, forgive my ignorance, then just declaring it with bean id "dispatcherServlet" would be enough.)

I'm happy to work with you to make this easier if it turns out to be hard for no good reason.

What does you app need those settings for, and how do you know they were ignored (AFAIK this is handled in the JVM itself, and nothing to do with Spring)? `JAVA_OPTS` should be included by the CLI (of you use the `spring` shell script that we provide). Can you see it in your running app (e.g. in visualvm or in an actuator /env endpoint or similar)? Can you provide some more detail, or steps to reproduce?

Hello Dave!
I understand first off you concern.  There maybe a better solution, but lets talk about the case.
While deploying Spring-XD to EC2 1 Admin, 1 Container, the container failed to connect to the redis server.  While investigating I noticed that the container's spring.redis.host had not been changed even though the spring_redis_host   environment variable was set.   What I found was that if I updated the application.yml spring: redis: host: the application would recognize the new host.

So I debugged the application and found that the PropertiesConfigurationFactory was filtering out the environment variables that contained a _ or a .   So for example spring_redis_port would be filtered by while port would not.

By adding the *_, the environment variable was allowed through and thus the application would use the spring_redis_host and spring_redis_port.  

Does this make sense?

With the latest snapshot of Spring Batch (2.2.4.BUILD-SNAPSHOT), the MySQL schema definition contains a new field in each of the sequence tables.  That field has a unique constraint on it so the default INSERT statements can't  be run more than once.  While this will cause an exception to be thrown in your logs the second time (due to the unique constraint being violated), it's not something that will stop the job from running.

  MultipartAutoConfiguration

Looking closer at that specific autoconfiguration code,

``` java
@Configuration
@ConditionalOnClass({ Servlet.class, StandardServletMultipartResolver.class })
@ConditionalOnBean(MultipartConfigElement.class)
public class MultipartAutoConfiguration {

        @Bean
        public StandardServletMultipartResolver multipartResolver() {
                return new StandardServletMultipartResolver();
        }

}
```

...I can clearly see three @Conditional's: `Servlet.class`, `StandardServletMultipartResolver.class`, and `MultipartConfigElement.class`. What might be happening is that somehow the `@ConditionalOnClass(Servlet.class)` isn't being handled properly or getting stomped on by the following conditional, and making it look like a duplicate.

Currently I see no clean solution how Spring boot can do this, since it should find out what logging system the user-code wants, but not what logging system it ships itself. spring-boot-starter-web depends on both log4j and logback, both will be included in a jar or war without further user action.
To make matters even worse, org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-actuator:0.5.0.M6 depends on org.slf4j:log4j-over-slf4j:1.7.5, conflicting with org.slf4j:slf4j-log4j12

I don't think this is really a problem, except for the user that has to do all the manual build configuration. Log4J _is_ supported by the underlying spring-boot library. So if you really prefer to use it for logging you don't have to use the "starter" dependencies to use Spring Boot - they are curated dependency sets for getting started quickly. If you really don't like logback (our preference) then you need to exclude logback from the web starter and log4j-over-slf4j from the actuator starter. Or you can include only the spring-boot bits you like (spring-boot-actuator on its own for instance has no dependency on a logging framework other than the commons-logging API, like most Spring projects).
